metadata.title: Dysphagia  Eagle Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Throat; ears; neck; face; elongated styloid process of the temporal bone or calcified stylohyoid ligament(1)
description: Eagle syndrome is characterized by a group of symptoms including recurrent throat and ear pain, globus (the sensation of a foreign body in the throat), occipital pain, dysphagia, and/or facial pain.(1,2,3,4) Eagle syndrome results from either an elongated styloid process of the temporal bone (greater than 3 cm in length) or a calcified stylohyoid ligament.(1,5,6) All individuals with elongated styloid processes will not necessarily be symptomatic, and the length of the styloid process does not directly correlate with the amount of pain experienced by an individual patient.(2,7) The syndrome is named for Watt W. Eagle, who coined the term stylalgia to describe the pain associated with Eagle syndrome.(2) There are two types of Eagle syndrome:
Classic type: marked by pain as a result of stimulation of cranial nerves V , VII, IX, and X and usually occurs after a tonsillectomy(2)

Carotid artery type (also called stylocarotid type): occurs when the styloid process becomes elongated and involves the carotid nerve plexus, causing globus and neck pain with head rotation(2,3) –This type of Eagle syndrome (especially when both of the styloid processes are elongated) is associated with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and/or syncope (loss of consciousness)(3,8,9)

ICD-9 codes.521.89: other specific diseases of hard tissues of teeth
ICD-9 codes.526.81: other specified diseases of the jaw

728.base: disorders of muscle, ligament, and fascia
728.728.8: other disorders of muscle, ligament, and fascia

ICD-9 codes.733.99: other disorders of bone and cartilage

ICD-10 codes.M85.88: other specified disorders of bone density and structure, other site
ICD-10 codes.R13.19: other dysphagia _ (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

Swallowing G-code set.G8996: Swallowing functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Swallowing G-code set.G8997: Swallowing functional limitation, projected goal status, at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Swallowing G-code set.G8998: Swallowing functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to impaired swallowing due to an inability to move food efficiently during the oral, pharyngeal, or esophageal phase of swallowing.(10) The oral phase includes sucking, chewing, and moving food or liquid into the throat. The pharyngeal phase is the initiation of the swallowing reflex, when food or liquid is squeezed down the throat and the airway is closed off to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking. In the esophageal phase, the openings at the top and bottom of the esophagus move food or liquid into the stomach by relaxing and  tightening.(11) Eagle syndrome can occur unilaterally or bilaterally (most typically it occurs unilaterally) and most frequently causes headache, pain on rotation of the neck, pain on extension of the tongue, change in voice, odynophagia (pain with swallowing), swelling, and a sensation of hypersalivation, all of which can interfere with normal swallowing and result in dysphagia.(2,7,22,23,24) In addition to causing pain, Eagle syndrome sometimes results in impaired sensation in the larynx which can lead to silent aspiration (the absence of coughing or throat clearing when material penetrates below the level of the vocal folds).(24) Authors of a case study reported a case of a 60-year-old  female with Eagle syndrome who had bilateral elongation of the styloid processes, but only experienced symptoms unilaterally(22) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain level, fatigue level, and frustration level. Pain is a significant issue related to swallowing for patients with Eagle syndrome(7)
A patient’s culture and native language should be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake
It is recommended that the caregiver/family be involved in all assessment procedures

pathogenesis: There are several theories regarding the way in which the styloid process elongation or ligament calcification occurs inEagle syndrome. These theories include:–Congenital elongation of the styloid process as a result of the persistence of a cartilaginous analog of the stylohyal (one ofthe embryologic precursors of the styloid)(5,6,7,12)–Idiopathic calcification of the stylohyoid ligament process(6,7,12)–Growth of osseous tissue at the insertion of the stylohyoid ligament(6,7,12)

The pathophysiological mechanism of the symptoms associated with Eagle syndrome is debated as well.(7) Theories of themechanism include:–A traumatic fracture of the styloid process causes proliferation of granulation tissue, thereby placing pressure on thesurrounding structures, resulting in pain(13)–Degenerative and inflammatory changes in the tendinous portion of the stylohyoid insertion, referred to as insertiontendonitis(12)–An irritation of the pharyngeal mucosa from direct compression or post-tonsillectomy  scarring that affects cranial nervesV , VII, IX, and X(2,12)–Impingement of the carotid vessels that produces irritation of the sympathetic nerves in the arterial sheath(12)
risk factors: Trauma to the jaw and/or neck(2,3,4)

overall contraindications precautions: Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) are required to have graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training in dysphagia assessment and treatment(14)
To perform videofluoroscopic swallowing studies (VFSSs), SLPs must have established competencies in the use and storage of barium used in VFSSs(15)

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and/or penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of the risk of aspiration and are educated about prevention strategies when appropriate
The patient’s family/caregivers should be involved in assessment and treatment procedures
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain level, fatigue level, and frustration level. Pain is a significant issue related to swallowing for patients with Eagle syndrome(7)
A patient’s culture and native language should be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake
It is recommended that the caregiver/family be involved in all assessment procedures

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review patient’s medical chart. How long has the patient experienced the symptoms associated with Eagle syndrome and when was the diagnosis of Eagle syndrome made? -Patients with Eagle syndrome often see multiple physicians and specialists prior to receiving an accurate diagnosis(2)

course of treatment.medical management: Document the patient’s medical management of Eagle syndrome including surgical and nonsurgical (e.g., analgesics, antiinflammatory  medications) interventions(1,22) Surgical intervention for Eagle syndrome involves removal of the elongated styloid process or calcified portion of the stylohyoid ligament(2,7) Surgical approaches for Eagle syndrome are intraoral and extraoral(16) Surgery is indicated for patients who do not respond to nonsurgical options for treatment of Eagle syndrome(22)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory  drugs (NSAIDs)(7,17) Steroid injections(7,17)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual tests for this condition are the following:
CT scan of the head and neck(2,7,8)
Angiography (when there is compression of the carotid artery)(8,9)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient exhibit increased swallowing difficulty -With certain textures of foods or liquids? -In different environments? -As meals progress? -During certain times of day? -If fatigued? -With environmental distractions?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much) -Patients with Eagle syndrome sometimes report “shooting” pains in the ear or jaw that last for a few minutes and then disappear(7) -The pain associated with Eagle syndrome can be worse with swallowing, oral motor movements, and head/neck positions and rotations(2,16) -First-bite  syndrome (FBS) can occur after operations on the parapharyngeal space and has been reported after surgical intervention for Eagle syndrome. The main symptom is excruciating pain that only occurs after the first one or two bites of meals(18) -Management for FBS is usually pain medication(18)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables; document if there is an increase in symptoms as the meal progresses
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status of the patient, including need for supplemental oxygen, history of mechanical ventilation, and presence of a tracheostomy tubeDocument psychosocial status. Review reports from mental health professional if available -Patients with Eagle syndrome who have significant pain can become chronically depressed and/or socially isolated(4)Document hearing ability Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _____________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document history of dysphagia; dental, jaw, throat, neck, or ear pain; trauma; stroke/TIA; loss of consciousness; surgeries; or dental, jaw, throat, neck, or ear disorders(2) Patients with Eagle syndrome often have a history of tonsillectomy(2,7)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Refer to medical charts and ask patient or patient’s family about other problems, including depression, hearing loss, vision problems, heart problems, communication difficulties, and memory loss
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient work? Does the patient participate in hobbies that may lead to pain or fatigue? Does the patient engage in social mealtimes?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate (e.g., pen/paper, communication board). Does the patient self-feed?  Is the patient limited to eating foods of certain textures only? Who prepares the patient’s food?
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, e.g., family members, caregivers). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document the presence of any mass or abnormality of the neck, jaw, or larynx to palpation; patients with Eagle syndrome sometimes have solid or sharp masses along the jaw, neck, or tonsillar fossa that can be felt by palpation.(4,5,7,16) Masses can be unilateral or bilateral(7,16)
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Examine the structure and range, rate, coordination, and symmetry of movement of the lips, facial musculature, tongue, pharynx, and larynx; document pain at rest and with movement or touch(16)
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: The purpose of a swallow examination is to determine if the patient has dysphagia, to determine which function is disordered, and to establish any compensatory strategies (change in swallowing manner or food consistency) that would be safe and beneficial to the patientA BSE is usually the first part of a comprehensive swallowing examination or is used as an initial screening to determine the need for further evaluation(14)In-depth  Bedside SwallowT709037(24) A VFSS is performed in collaboration with a physician (radiologist or physiatrist) and an SLP or occupational therapist and is used primarily as a diagnostic procedure for dysphagia.(14) The patient eats and drinks a variety of developmentally appropriate liquids and solids mixed with barium while images are recorded with videofluorography. All patients should be examined in the lateral and frontal positions to gain information on movements of the swallow and symmetry of bolus flow and pharyngeal wall contraction. The SLP examines for the presence of aspiration and the effectiveness of presenting different  food consistencies or of modifying posture.(11) Most clinical practices follow the protocol originally described by Logemann(19) -In patients with Eagle syndrome, the elongated styloid process might be visible in the lateral view on a VFSS(23)Modified BariumT709046(24) FEES is performed to evaluate the anatomy and physiology of the pharynx and the larynx, pharyngeal swallow function, and the patient’s ability to manage secretions and swallow foods and liquids.(11) In addition, it can be used to explore a variety of diagnostic interventions, such as varying bolus consistency, varying posture, or making use of visual feedback for reinforcement.(25) After the insertion of the endoscope, the patient can engage in normal feeding behavior during the evaluation. Food must be light in color to enhance visibility (e.g., milk, puddings, yogurt, bread). FEES is preferred over VFSS when patients have safety issues related to radiation exposure or when they need retesting. The American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association has published several online documents relevant to the technical aspects of FEES and the qualifications required to perform FEES(26) -For detailed information on FEES and endoscopic examinations for dysphagia, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and are educated about prevention strategies when appropriate

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Dysphagia diagnosis and management are based on the results of a comprehensive assessment that is performed by an SLP in collaboration with the patient’s primary physician and/or an otolaryngologist. The primary goal is to maintain and maximize the patient’s health status.(14) After the evaluation, a decision must be made about the patient’s ability to ingest food and liquids orally based on the nature of the disorder and the patient’s ability to make adjustments. With Eagle syndrome the patient is unlikely to require speech therapy intervention, as pain and dysphagia are resolved with medical and surgical intervention(2,5,7,16,20)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out other possible causes of the pain and/or dysphagia, including Cervical arthritis Esophageal diverticula Faulty dental prostheses Fibromyalgia Glossopharyngeal neuralgia Hyoid bursitis Laryngopharyngeal dysesthesia Migraine-type  headaches Otitis Salivary gland disease Sluder syndrome Sphenopalatine neuralgia Temporal arthritis Temporomandibular disorders Trigeminal neuralgia Tumors Unerupted or impacted molar teeth
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines The patient with Eagle syndrome should be followed by an otolaryngologist (ENT);(2) refer the patient if he or she is not already under the care of an ENT Physical therapy for cervical neck pain(3)

improved quality of life: SWAL-QOL:  An outcome measure that includes patient self-ratings  of quality of life due to swallowing and eatingability(21)

maintenance or prevention: There is no known prevention for Eagle syndrome
patient education: Online support group for patients with Eagle syndrome, http://www.livingwitheagle.org/
See “Swallowing Disorders (Dysphagia) in Adults” from the American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association, http:// www.asha.org/public/speech/swallowing/SwallowingAdults.htm Note
